timeline.bodyText: This is super fragile and fails if we have Widget implements ConfigurablePlugin<WidgetInfo> and then NewerWidget extends Widget
timeline.author: madrob

timeline.bodyText: At the very least, don't suppress raw types here.
timeline.author: madrob

timeline.bodyText: Does T need to extend PluginMeta as you do in the unit test or no?
timeline.author: madrob

replies.bodyText: No,it does not have to. I did it to make writing the test easy
replies.author: noblepaul

timeline.bodyText: Is this a security risk? Why do we need this?
timeline.author: madrob

replies.bodyText: This is not a security risk. In general it's better to ignore extra attributes for backcompat. Imagine adding an extra attribute to your plugin in a newer version and old Solr nodes failing because of that
replies.author: noblepaul

timeline.bodyText: Maybe configure(T cfg)? the current name looks awkward.
timeline.author: sigram

timeline.bodyText: ObjectMapper is a relatively heavy object, we should not create new instances in every class that needs it - maybe put a common instance somewhere in Utils?
timeline.author: sigram

timeline.bodyText: Does PluginMeta still need a separate pathPrefix? I think this could become a config property.
timeline.author: sigram

replies.bodyText: It's a standard property , that is a part of the plugin definition
replies.author: noblepaul

replies.bodyText: It made sense when all plugins were request handlers, which is no longer true. In case of plugins that are not handlers a "standard" pathPrefix property doesn't make sense.
replies.author: sigram

replies.bodyText: PluginMeta is the information used by the framework. It's optional, so your plugin can choose to ignore it
replies.author: noblepaul

replies.bodyText: I know that I can ignore it - my point was that this property is a relic of the time when we allowed only Api handlers as plugins. Now when non-Api plugins are first-class citizens half of the time this property doesn't make sense because it's specific only to Api plugins - so it should not be exposed as a standard property for all plugins.
replies.author: sigram

replies.bodyText:
It can be a specific sub-class of PluginMeta say EndPointPluginMeta .
However, that change does not belong here
replies.author: noblepaul

replies.bodyText:
Let's make it a sub-class.
(I would argue that it belongs in this PR because it's a part of the configuration mechanism for the plugins that this PR defines. Since we are adding a flexible config bean it doesn't make sense to still keep the old primitive field. And you can always ADD fields in subclasses but removing them is much harder... ;) )
replies.author: sigram

timeline.author: sigram

timeline.bodyText: This example may be confusing because in general case configuration classes don't have to subclass PluginMeta. I propose removing this subclassing here to make it clear that's the case.
timeline.author: sigram

timeline.message: incorporating several review feedbacks. Added more tests. Changed the config object type

timeline.bodyText:
I don't understand this change. Do all config beans have to implement ReflectMapWriter?
If that's the case, and all config beans have to implement ReflectMapWriter then that's what the generic type in ConfigurablePlugin should use. If not then this test is misleading again because it suggests you have to implement additional interfaces to have a usable config bean.
timeline.author: sigram

replies.bodyText: Then we have to explicitly say so in ConfigurablePlugin<T extends MapWriter>.
replies.author: sigram

timeline.bodyText:
Oh, I didn't notice before that it was created for each request. That was horrible!
Still, we already have one instance here and another (configured the same) in ContainerPluginsRegistry. We should probably expose this instance here and reuse it in ContainerPluginsRegistry.
timeline.author: sigram

replies.bodyText: It was not created per request. it was created per API
replies.author: noblepaul

timeline.bodyText: Should this be <T extends ReflectMapWriter> ? See my comment below in TestContainerPlugin.java
timeline.author: sigram
